You're correct that each time you roll the die the outcome is not dependent on previous outcomes. However, that's not the way to look at it.  The sample space is the same as if you were rolling five dice at once, and asking the chance of at least one of them coming up with a two.  If you remember the example of rolling two dice, out of 36 possibilities there was a cell that represented getting a two on both dice.  That cell had to be subtracted out of the favourable outcomes when you added them up, 6 + 6 -1, or 11/36.  (6 chances to get a 2 on die A, 6 chances to get a 2 on die B, and one chance to get a two on both dice at once).  Notice also that the suggested approach gives (1 - 5/6 * 5/6) or (1 - 25/36) or 11/36 - same answer.  This question deals with five dice, so unless you're good at visualizing a five dimensional space, it gets a little tricky to count the cells.  Again, the five rolls are independent of each other, just like five separate dice are independent, but the sample space counts outcomes, which are not independent.

Typically if you are making a number of trials of the same type, such as rolling a die, flipping a coin, drawing a card, then the sample space is the number of outcomes of each trial raised to the power of the number of trials.  So three die rolls gives you a space of 6^3, ten coin flips would be 2^10, five cards drawn would be 52^5 (assuming you are replacing the card and reshuffling each time).  Factorials get involved when the sample space involves arrangements of items in a particular order.  For example what is the chance that you could shuffle five cards and deal them out in increasing order, ace, two, three, four, and five.  That's one arrangement of a sample space of 5 factorial, or 1/120.

title: a correction to the guess of Mr. Winston; RANK.AVG function; if there are same values in the data
comment_text:
I tried what Mr. Winston said about ranking. I prepared a data set "scores" which includes twice the score of 1; includes three times the score of 2; includes four times the score of 3; and includes once the scores of 4, 5, 6, 7. I used RANK.AVG function with ascending order. I add a picture of it below. What I see is different from what Mr. Winston said. For the scores of 2, there are three times the scores of 2 and RANK.AVG didn't give a value such as 2.33. (Mr. Winston had said that: "*If three tied, **I guess** it would be 21.33, something like that.*" - I also added what he said below.)

if there are same values in the data, RANK.AVG formula gives the rank of middle value of these values.

More precisely, it gives the average of ranks of the values if there are same values in the data.

If the number of values are odd, (I mean If there are 3, 5, 7 etc. number of values), RANK.AVG function gives the rank of the middle value for all of these same values. Let's say, there are three same values, it will give the rank of the second one (second one is the middle of three values). Or let's say, there are nine same values, it will give the rank of the fifth one (fifth one is the middle of nine values). In my example, which I added its picture in this post, there are three times the score of 2 (In A4, A5, and A6 cells). Because the rank of the middle value is 4 (it is score of 2 in A5 cell), excel gives the rank of 4 for all scores of 2. (B4, B5, B6 all of them are 4)

If the number of values are even, (I mean If there are 2, 4, 6 etc. number of values), RANK.AVG function gives the rank of the middle value for all of these same values. If the number of values are even, excel gives a decimal which ends with .5 because there isn't an exact middle value. There are two middle values. It will give the averages of ranks. Let's say, there are four same values, it will give the rank of the middle values. Because there isn't an exact value between 2nd and 3rd values, excel takes the rank of the second value and adds .5 integer. It means its rank is between 2nd and 3rd values. In my example, which I added its picture in this post, there are four times the score of 3 (In A7, A8, A9 and A10 cells). The ranks of middle values for the scores of 3 are 7 and 8. So, it gives the rank of 7.5 for the all the scores of 3.

As is told in the video, Bayes Theorem essentially shows the share of true positive test results in the total of positive test results (true and false) and thereby gives an indication of the level of trust you can have in a positive test result.
